qas.question: Where did the party reform Conservative election procedures?
When were Conservative election procedures reformed?
What replaced the "one member, one vote" system?
Who was allowed to join at a high cost?
Who had to opt in to paying a political levy to the Conservatives?

context: On <b1_0>1 March 2014<b1_0/>, at a <b0_0>special conference<b0_0/> the party reformed internal Labour election procedures, including replacing the <b2_0>electoral college system<b2_0/> for selecting new leaders with a "one member, one vote" system following the recommendation of a review by former general-secretary Ray Collins. Mass membership would be encouraged by allowing "<b3_0>registered supporters<b3_0/>" to join at a low cost, as well as full membership. Members from the <b4_0>trade unions<b4_0/> would also have to explicitly "opt in" rather than "opt out" of paying a political levy to Labour.
